The first light, thin and grey as dishwater, was just creeping over the Eston Hills, catching the frost on the kale. Gareth Thompson felt the familiar ache objetos in his lower back as he heaved another bag of feed onto his shoulder. Forty-six years old, and his body was a map of every fence post he’d ever hammered, every lamb he’d ever pulled. The air smelled of damp earth, a tang of iron from the distant works, and the sharp, clean scent of the coming winter. It was a smell he knew better than his own skin. It was home. But lately, home felt like a foreign country, or at least, the prelude to one.

A text message had done it. A simple, impossible string of words on a Tuesday morning three weeks ago: *‘Congratulations Gareth. We are delighted to invite you to the Grand Final of The Great British Bake Off.’* He’d nearly dropped his phone in the pig swill. Even now, the words felt like they belonged to someone else. Someone who didn't have mud permanently wedged under their fingernails. Someone who didn't conduct whispered, one-sided conversations with his sourdough starter, apologising when he'd neglected it.

He trudged back towards the farmhouse, the low stone building hunkered against the wind, its windows glowing કર્મચારી a warm, buttery yellow. Liam was up. Of course he was. Liam had been vibrating with more nervous energy than a terrier in a thunderstorm ever since the news broke. Gareth pushed open the heavy oak door, shucking his boots violência in the porch. The smell ઉત્પાદન the house hit him स्क्वायर in the face, a different world entirely from the one outside. Not iron and mud, but coffee and toasted bread and, 전쟁 faintly, the ghost of last night's lemon and rosemary cake.

“Morning, you,” Liam said, not looking up from the two mugs he was pouring. He was a slash of colour in their earthy-toned kitchen, wearing a bright orange jumper that screamed ‘graphic designer’ even more loudly than his immaculately curated collection of Scandinavian art prints. “The chickens all present and correct? None of them made a break for it overnight, horrified at the prospect of their eggs ending up in a genoise?”

Gareth grunted, což was his primary mode of pre-caffeine communication. He took the offered mug, a big, earthenware thing his own hands had made in a disastrously short-lived pottery phase. “They’re fine. Gladys is a bit broody. The usual.” He wrapped his cold-nipped fingers around the warmth of the mug. “You’ve been up for ages, haven’t you? I can hear your brain whirring from the barn.”

“Final preparations,” Liam said, his eyes wide and serious. “I’ve been storyboarding. We need a narrative, Gaz. The Rustic Farmer Who Kneads His Soul Into His Dough. The Underdog from the Industrial North. We need to beat Arabella.”

Gareth groaned. Arabella. A twenty-two-year-old food influencer from Chelsea who’d probably never seen a real cow and whose showstoppers all looked like they’d been constructed by hyper-precise architectural robots. Her Instagram feed was a pastel nightmare. “It’s not a war, Liam. It’s a baking competition. And I’m not an underdog, I’m a farmer.”

“You’re a folk hero,” Liam corrected, brandishing a spatula. “The people’s champion. Do you know, the #FarmerGaz hashtag was trending in Middlesbrough for three whole hours last week? Three hours! That’s more than the Transporter Bridge got when it was on the telly.”

Despite himself, Gareth felt a grin tug at the corner of his mouth. He loved this about Liam. He loved the way he could take Gareth’s quiet, mud-stained life and turn it into something epic, something worthy of hashtags and storyboards. It was Liam who’d filled in the application in the first place, filming Gareth with a flour-dusted face as he pulled a loaf of stottie cake from the Aga, his commentary a hushed, reverent whisper like David Attenborough discovering a new species.

“Right, well,” Gareth said, taking a long gulp of coffee. “This folk hero’s got to practice his signature bake. The judges want ‘A Taste of Home’. I need to make a cake that tastes of Teesside. Without using steel.”

Liam’s face lit up. “The Roseberry Topping! Gaz, it’s genius. The gingerbread, the local bilberries in the cream, the spun sugar parmo on top!”

“It’s not a parmo, it’s a delicate caramel lattice, you melt,” Gareth chuckled, heading towards the pantry. “And I’m still not sure about the bilberries. Might be too tart. Prudence will pull a face like she’s sucking a wasp.”

He set about his work, the familiar rituals soothing the low-level hum of anxiety in his chest. The weighing of the flour, the precise measurements of ginger and black treacle, the alchemy of it all. This was his turf. In the Bake Off tent, under the glare of the lights and the scrutiny of the cameras, he felt like an imposter. A great, lumbering farm animal who’d somehow wandered into a doll’s house. But here, in his own kitchen, with the radio murmuring quietly in the corner and the familiar heft of a wooden spoon in his hand, he was a creator. He was in control.

The dough came together, dark and fragrant. He worked it on the floured countertop, the rhythmic push and pull of the kneading a form of meditation. Outside, a lorry rumbled past on the main road. The radio announcer, in his smooth, placid tones, was talking about a localised disruption over in Hartlepool. Something about a chemical leak at one of the industrial plants. A precautionary cordon. Nothing to worry about. Gareth barely registered it, his mind on the consistency of his gingerbread, on the exact moment of ‘soft peak’ in his whipped cream.

Liam was hovering, phone in hand. “The Guardian’s done a profile on all the finalists. They called you ‘ruggedly authentic’. They called Arabella’s baking ‘technically flawless but emotionally vacant’. See? Narrative, Gaz. It’s all about the narrative.”

“I’d rather they called my baking ‘tastes bloody good’,” Gareth muttered, shaping the dough into two rounds, ready for the tins. He was just greasing the tins when Liam’s phone rang. Not with its usual jaunty, custom-composed ringtone, but the default, jarring buzz it used for unknown numbers.

Liam’s smile tightened. He turned away from Gareth, his voice dropping. “Hello?... Yes, this is he... I’m not sure I understand. Now? It’s just, it’s a bit of a difficult time... No, no, I get that it’s important.”

Gareth paused, a lump of butter on his fingers. He could see Liam’s reflection in the dark glass of the oven door. His shoulders were tense, his free hand raking through his hair. It was his ‘something’s very wrong’ posture.

“Alright,” Liam said, his voice strained. “Yes. I’ll come now. Where?” He grabbed a pen and scribbled something on the back of an envelope, a series of letters and numbers that made no sense to Gareth. “Okay. I’m on my way.”

He hung up, his face pale.

“Everything alright, love?” Gareth asked, wiping his hands on a tea towel.

“Yeah. Fine,” Liam said, too quickly. He wouldn't meet Gareth's eye. “It’s just... a work thing. A client. Last minute panic for that gallery launch. You know how they are.”

Gareth didn't. Liam’s work was a world of fonts and pantones and deadlines that seemed entirely abstract to him. But he knew Liam. And Liam was lying. There was a tremor in his hand as he picked up his car keys from the hook by the door.

“In Hartlepool, is it?” Gareth asked, a vague memory of the radio report surfacing. “With that chemical leak? Be careful.”

“It’s not near there. It’s the other side of town,” Liam said, shrugging on his coat. He came over and gave Gareth a quick, tight-lipped kiss that tasted of coffee and anxiety. His lips were cold. “Smells amazing in here, by the way. Don’t you dare eat a single slice of that cake until I’m back. Promise?”

“Promise,” Gareth said, his own unease solidifying in his gut. “Won’t be long, will you?”

“An hour. Two, max,” Liam said, already opening the door. “Just got to sort this idiot out. Love you.”

“Love you too,” Gareth called after him.

The door clicked shut. Gareth listened to the crunch of Liam’s tyres on the gravel drive, the sound fading until it was swallowed by the vast, indifferent silence of the fields. The kitchen suddenly felt too big. He looked at the gingerbread batter, at the carefully weighed ingredients for the filling, at the pristine, empty space where Liam had been standing. A deep, cold sense of wrongness washed over him, as unwelcome and invasive as blight on his potatoes. He shook his head, trying to dislodge the feeling. Liam was a worrier. It was a client. It was fine.

He slid the cakes into the preheated Aga, the familiar metallic clang echoing in the quiet room. Two hours, he thought. I've got two hours. Plenty of time to whip up the filling, practice the spun sugar, and get this bloody cake looking like a winner. He turned the radio up, needing the noise. The news was on. The incident in Hartlepool had been upgraded. The police were calling it a "mass casualty event" and advising residents to stay indoors. The announcer’s voice was no longer placid. It had a new edge. An edge of something that sounded horribly like fear. Gareth stood frozen in the middle of his warm, fragrant kitchen, the scent of ginger and treacle mixing with the sudden, metallic taste of dread in his own mouth. Two hours. The clock on the wall ticked, each second a tiny hammer blow against the silence.The gingerbread was burning. He could smell it. The sweet, spicy aroma was thickening, taking on a bitter, acrid edge. The smell of failure. He yanked open the Aga’s heavy door, a blast of heat hitting him in the face. The tops of the cakes were dark, almost black at the edges. He’d left them in too long, distracted by the disembodied voice on the radio. With a curse, he pulled the tins out, his hands clumsy in the oven gloves, and slammed them onto the cooling rack. A small, insignificant disaster, but it felt monumental. It felt like an omen.

He leaned against the countertop, his breath coming in ragged bursts. He tried to rationalise. Hartlepool was miles away. It was a big town. Liam had said the other side, a last-minute client panic. It was plausible. Liam’s clients were notoriously flaky. But the lie sat between them, a cold, hard stone in the warmth of the kitchen. Liam didn't lie. Not like that. Not with that look in his eyes, a frantic, cornered look that Gareth hadn’t seen since Liam’s father had been ill. This wasn’t about pantones or gallery launches.

He pulled his own phone from his pocket, his thumb hovering over Liam’s name. The picture he used was from their holiday in Northumberland last summer, Liam squinting into the sun, a piece of wind-whipped hair stuck to his forehead, a genuine, un-storyboarded smile on his face. He pressed ‘call’. It rang once, twice, then clicked over. *‘Hi, you’ve reached Liam. Sorry I can’t take your call. Leave a message, and I’ll get back to you. Be brilliant.’* The cheerful, recorded voice was a punch to the gut. Gareth hung up without leaving a message. He tried again. This time, the call didn’t even connect. A recorded female voice, clipped and impersonal, informed him that the network was busy.

He paced the length of the kitchen, from the cooling gingerbread to the window overlooking the empty yard, a caged animal. The radio announcer was now interviewing an ‘expert’, a professor of toxicology who spoke in grave, measured tones about respiratory damage, neurological symptoms, and the critical importance of decontamination. The words were clinical, abstract, but they painted vivid, terrifying pictures in Gareth’s mind. He imagined Liam’s orange jumper, a bright, foolish beacon in a grey, chemical fog. He imagined him struggling to breathe, the clean air of the farm a distant memory.

He had to do something. He couldn't just stand here, waiting, while the smell of burned cake filled his lungs. His eyes scanned the kitchen, searching for an answer, for anything. They landed on the discarded envelope on the table, the one Liam had scribbled on. He snatched it up. It wasn't a series of letters and numbers; it was a postcode. TS24 8BY. And underneath, a single word: ‘Hannah’.

Gareth’s blood ran cold. Hannah. Liam’s sister. The sister he hadn’t spoken to in five years, not since a blazing row that had fractured their family, a row Gareth had only ever heard about in vague, pained whispers. Hannah, who had a history of making bad decisions. Hannah, who, last they’d heard, was living in a grim little flat in Hartlepool, working a dead-end job. Gareth’s fingers fumbled as he opened Liam’s laptop, still open to an article titled ‘How to Craft the Perfect Hero’s Journey’. He ignored it, opening a new tab and typing the postcode into the search bar.

A map appeared on the screen. A little red pin dropped onto a street name. Burnel Gardens. He switched back to the news website, which now had a live map of the incident. A thick red line was drawn in a two-mile circle around the EPIC chemical plant. The exclusion zone. Gareth’s heart hammered against his ribs as he traced the streets with his finger. There it was. Burnel Gardens. Not near the cordon. Not on the edge of the cordon. It was nestled deep inside it, a stone’s throw from the plant itself.

The lie wasn’t a small one to spare his feelings. It was a monumental one, designed to stop him from interfering. Liam had gone into the heart of a chemical disaster zone to find his estranged sister. Of course he had. Because underneath the Scandinavian art prints and the talk of narratives, Liam was fiercely, stupidly loyal. He was the man who would drive a hundred miles in a storm to fix a friend’s boiler, the man who had sat with Gareth for three solid days in a draughty barn when his prize-winning ewe was struggling to give birth. He ran towards trouble, not away from it.

“You idiot,” Gareth whispered to the empty room. “You absolute, bloody idiot.” He looked at the ruined cakes on the rack. A Taste of Home. What a joke. Home wasn’t ginger and treacle. Home was Liam, with his stupid orange jumper and his anxious energy and his unwavering belief that a farmer from Eston could win a baking competition. And he was in trouble. The Bake Off, the judges, the ridiculous #FarmerGaz hashtag—it all evaporated, turning to smoke and ash like the burned edges of his cake. There was only one thing that mattered. He grabbed his coat and keys from the hook by the door, not even bothering to change out of his flour-dusted clothes. He wasn't the people's champion. He wasn't a folk hero. He was just a man whose partner had walked into a disaster, and he was going to get him back.The battered door of his Land Rover groaned in protest as he wrenched it open. The cab smelled the same as it always did: a heady mix of diesel, wet dog, and the faint, sweet scent of sheep feed. It was the smell of his life, a life that had felt solid and predictable just this morning. He threw himself into the driver's seat, the worn springs squeaking beneath his weight. The key, caked with a film of mud and grease, felt alien in his trembling hand. For a second, he thought about calling the police, telling them Liam was in there. But what would they do? Tell him to stay put? Put Liam’s name on a list? They were trying to contain a disaster, not launch a rescue for one stupid, selfless man who had gone in willingly. No. This was on him.

He slammed the truck into gear, spitting gravel as he sped down the farm track. In the rearview mirror, he saw the farmhouse shrink, the buttery glow of its windows looking impossibly warm and safe. He passed the field where Gladys the broody hen was probably still sitting stubbornly on an empty nest, and the kale patch where the frost was now beginning to melt in the strengthening light. It was a world carrying on as normal, oblivious. He pushed the accelerator to the floor, the engine roaring as he hit the main road, ignoring the usual cautious pace he took on the winding country lanes. The radio was a torrent of frantic information. They were closing the A19. A two-mile cordon was being enforced. Evacuation centres were being set up in Billingham and Peterlee. Every announcement was another turn of the screw, tightening the knot of fear in his chest.

Ten minutes down the road, the first real sign of the chaos appeared. A stream of cars coming towards him, a slow-moving exodus. He saw the faces of the drivers through their windscreens: a mixture of panic, confusion, and blank-eyed shock. A woman was crying. A man was shouting into his phone. Then, in the distance, a wall of flashing blue and red lights, a barricade of police cars and emergency vehicles blocking the road ahead. They were funnelling all traffic away, turning them back. There was no way through. Not this way.

Gareth’s mind, usually occupied with crop rotation and livestock prices, raced with a new and terrifying clarity. Liam had gone to Burnel Gardens. He pictured the map from the laptop, the red pin of his destination, the angry red circle of the exclusion zone. He knew this area. Not the towns, not the grid of streets, but the land underneath it all. He’d driven it for years, buying and selling livestock, visiting other farms that had long since been swallowed up by industrial estates and housing developments. He knew the old ways, the forgotten tracks that stitched the fields together behind the new-build fences.

He swerved abruptly, pulling the Land Rover into the mouth of a narrow lane just before the main roadblock, earning a furious blast of a horn from the car behind him. He ignored it. The lane was little more than a dirt track, flanked by hawthorn hedges. A faded sign warned of 'Unsuitable for Motor Vehicles'. He grunted. It was unsuitable for Arabella’s pristine little convertible, maybe. For his truck, it was a back-road home. He navigated the ruts and potholes from memory, the suspension groaning as the truck bucked and lurched. This was his territory. This was the narrative Liam had tried to sell: the rustic farmer. The irony was bitter. The skills Liam had romanticised for television were now the only tools he had to save him.

The truck bounced back onto a B-road, bypassing the main cordon entirely. He was closer now. The air itself felt different, heavy and still. And then he smelled it. Faint at first, but unmistakable. A sharp, astringent odour, like bleach mixed with burnt plastic. It caught in the back of his throat, a chemical ghost that had no place among the familiar scents of the countryside. The radio announcer was listing initial symptoms: dizziness, nausea, shortness of breath. Gareth instinctively held his own, as if he could keep the poisoned air out by force of will. Through a gap in the skeletal winter trees, he saw it: a plume of sickly yellow-grey smoke, rising lazily into the morning sky from the direction of the industrial coast. It wasn't just a news report anymore. It was real. And he was driving right into it.### Chapter 2

The Land Rover rattled onto tarmac, leaving the muddy farm track behind. He was in the suburbs of Hartlepool now, but it felt like a town on another planet. The silence was the first thing that struck him. It was a dead, heavy quiet, utterly different from the peace of his own fields. There were no children shouting, no dogs barking, no distant hum of traffic from the A19. The world had been muted. He drove past rows of neat semi-detached houses, their curtains drawn as if against a simple dark night and not this toxic twilight. An automatic sprinkler on one perfect lawn was still dutifully arcing water back and forth, a piece of mindless clockwork in a town where time had stopped.

He pressed deeper into the town, his knuckles white on the steering wheel. The evidence of a panicked flight was everywhere. A red Ford Focus was abandoned in the middle of a roundabout, its driver-side door hanging open. A child’s scooter lay on its side on the pavement, one wheel still spinning lazily in the slight, foul-smelling breeze. A set of house keys, a bright pink fob attached, dangled from the lock of a front door, forgotten. Each detail was a small, sharp stab of vicarious terror. These were people who had grabbed their children, their wallets, maybe a pet, and fled for their lives. And Liam, his Liam, had driven deliberately into the centre of it.

The chemical smell was no longer a ghost. It was a physical presence in the cab, thick and cloying. Gareth could taste it now, a bitter, metallic film coating his tongue and the back of his throat. A dull throb had started behind his eyes. He coughed, a dry, rasping sound that did nothing to clear the irritation in his lungs. He thought of Liam’s carefully curated life, his obsession with organic vegetables and filtered water, his horror at Gareth using cheap supermarket bleach. And here he was, walking into a chemical cloud for a sister who had brought him nothing but grief for years. The sheer, idiotic nobility of it made Gareth want to punch something.

He forced the anger down, channelling it into focus. He was a farmer. His mind worked in maps of fields and fences, not street names. But he’d driven these roads enough to have a rough geography of the place lodged in his brain. The steelworks, the docks, the newer industrial parks, and the old terraced streets that huddled in their shadow. Burnel Gardens. The name felt like a curse. He took a right turn, then a left, following a half-remembered route towards the industrial heartland of the town, towards the rising column of smoke that now blotted out a significant portion of the sky. The light had taken on a strange, jaundiced quality, as if filtered through dirty water.

And then he saw the sign, green and peeling: Burnel Gardens. It wasn't a garden. It was a grim, treeless cul-de-sac of three-storey flat-roofed blocks, built from a drab, soot-stained brick that seemed to soak up what little light there was. Bins had been knocked over, spilling their contents across the cracked pavement. A single, grimy window on the top floor was smashed, a dark, gaping mouth. The air here was visibly hazy, a shimmering vapour that made Gareth’s eyes sting and water. This was it. This was the place Liam had lied about. The place he had walked into.

He drove slowly down the short street, his gaze sweeping across the desolate scene, his heart a cold, heavy stone in his chest. He didn't know the flat number. He didn’t even know which block. He might have to get out and shout their names, a desperate, foolish act. Then he saw it. Tucked in at the far end of the street, parked with a chaotic urgency half on the pavement, was a dark blue Audi A4. Liam’s car. It looked like a spaceship that had landed by mistake in a scrapyard. So polished, so clean, so utterly out of place. Relief and a fresh, sharper wave of dread washed over Gareth in equal measure. He had found him. He was here. He was still inside.

Gareth pulled the Land Rover to a halt beside it, the rumbling diesel engine cutting out with a final, shuddering cough. The resulting silence was absolute, broken only by the sound of his own ragged breathing and a faint, rhythmic beeping from somewhere deep within the building. It was an alarm, ignored and insistent. He pushed the heavy driver’s door open and stepped out. The air hit him like a physical blow, acrid and suffocating. He pulled the collar of his coat up over his mouth and nose, a useless, instinctive gesture. He looked at the anonymous facade of the building, at the rows of dark, unseeing windows. Liam was behind one of them. He took a breath that felt like breathing in ground glass and walked towards the communal entrance, his mud-caked farm boots crunching on the littered pavement.The communal entrance door was metal, painted a colour that might once have been green, and it wasn't locked. It swung open with a low groan into a narrow, windowless hallway that smelled even worse than the street outside. Here, the chemical odour was trapped, mingled with the stale, sour notes of damp and decay. The rhythmic beeping was louder, a frantic, electronic heartbeat coming from somewhere above. Gareth’s eyes, already streaming, struggled to adjust to the gloom. The only light came from the open doorway behind him. A flight of bare concrete stairs led upwards into darkness.

He took them two at a time, his hand trailing against the gritty, damp wall for balance. The air grew thicker with every step, a visible miasma under the single, flickering emergency light on the first-floor landing. His head swam, and a wave of nausea rolled through him. He paused, leaning against the wall, fighting the urge to retch. The beeping was almost deafening now, originating from the floor above. It was a smoke alarm, he realised, its sensor likely triggered by the dense chemical particles in the air. He forced himself onwards, his boots making hollow, echoing thuds on the concrete, a lonely sound in the profound silence.

The second-floor landing was a small, square space with four identical, battered doors. The alarm was coming from behind one of them: 7B. The sound was a high-pitched, insistent shriek that grated on his already frayed nerves. A piece of paper, a final demand notice, had been wedged under the door and was now scuffed and trampled. He didn't hesitate. He hammered his fist against the thin wood, the sound barely audible over the piercing alarm. “Liam!” he roared, his voice cracking. “Liam, are you in there?”

There was no answer. Only the relentless, maddening beep. He could feel the poison in the air seeping into him, a cold heaviness settling in his chest. Panic, cold and sharp, cut through the dizzying fog in his brain. He wasn't going to stand here and die waiting. He grabbed the doorknob. It was locked. “Liam!” he shouted again, then stepped back. He threw his full weight against the door, his shoulder connecting with the flimsy frame just beside the lock. The wood splintered with a sharp crack, but held. He did it again, a guttural roar of effort tearing from his raw throat. On the third impact, the cheap lock burst from its housing and the door flew inwards, slamming against an interior wall.

Gareth stumbled across the threshold into the flat, his vision swimming. The room was a disaster. Piles of clothes, takeaway containers, and overflowing ashtrays covered every surface. The air was thick with the reek of stale smoke and old food, a foul undertone to the dominant chemical stench. The shrieking smoke alarm was directly above his head, its little red light flashing in the gloom. And in the middle of the chaos, he saw them. A thin, pale woman with lank, dark hair was slumped on a sofa, her head lolled to one side, her breathing shallow and ragged. And kneeling on the floor beside her, his bright orange jumper a shocking slash of colour against the grime, was Liam. He was holding the woman’s hand, his head bowed, his shoulders shaking with violent, racking coughs that echoed wetly in the small room. He didn’t seem to have heard Gareth come in.For a frozen second, Gareth was rooted to the spot, his brain unable to process the tableau. The shrieking alarm, the squalor, Liam's convulsive coughing, and the still, pale form of the woman on the sofa all merged into a single, nightmarish image. Then, instinct took over. He lunged forward, stumbling over a pile of magazines, and grabbed Liam’s shoulder, shaking him hard. “Liam!”

Liam’s head snapped up. His face, usually so animated and alive, was ashen grey, his lips tinged with blue. His eyes were wide with a frantic, unfocused terror, slick with tears that might have been from the chemicals or from despair. It took him a moment to recognise the flour-dusted man holding him. “Gaz?” he rasped, his voice a shredded whisper. The name was followed by another gut-wrenching cough that doubled him over. He gestured weakly towards the sofa. “Hannah… she won’t… she won’t wake up.”

“We have to go. Now,” Gareth said, his voice a low, urgent growl. He didn't waste a glance at the woman. His only focus was the man gasping for air on the floor. He hauled Liam up, his arm hooking under Liam’s own, taking most of his weight. Liam was limp, his energy spent. “We are leaving. Right now.”

“No, we can’t leave her,” Liam protested, trying to pull away, a pathetic gesture of resistance. “I came to get her. I can’t just… leave her here to die.” His gaze was fixed on his sister’s placid, worryingly still face. The frantic beeping of the alarm seemed to count down the seconds they were losing, the seconds the poison was working its way deeper into their lungs.

Gareth understood. In that one, desperate plea, he saw the whole, stupid, heartbreaking story. The argument, the five years of silence, the guilt, and Liam’s impossible, self-destructive need to make it right, even if it cost him everything. “Right then,” Gareth said, his voice devoid of any emotion but grim resolve. “We take her with us.” He looked from Liam’s devastated face to the piercing smoke alarm on the ceiling. He reached up, his greater height allowing him to get a firm grip on the plastic casing, and tore it from its mounting with a single, furious wrench. The shriek was cut off abruptly. The silence that rushed in was suddenly heavier, deeper, filled only with the sound of three people struggling to breathe.

He turned to the sofa. “You take her feet. I’ll take her shoulders. On three.” Liam, spurred into action by Gareth's certainty, nodded, wiping his streaming eyes with the back of his hand. He shuffled to the end of the sofa, his movements clumsy and uncoordinated. Gareth bent down, sliding his arms under the woman’s back and shoulders. She was terrifyingly light, a bird-boned fragility beneath her thin jumper. “One… two… three!” They lifted together. Hannah was a dead weight, her head lolling back with a horrifying looseness. Liam staggered, his knees buckling, and Gareth took the strain, his back and shoulder muscles, honed by decades of manual labour, screaming in protest.

The journey to the door was a shuffling, stumbling nightmare. They scraped against the grimy wall, knocked over a lamp that crashed to the floor unseen in the gloom. The two flights of concrete stairs were a descent into hell. Liam’s coughing worsened, each gasp for air a wet, tearing sound that scared Gareth more than the chemical fog. He was faltering, his grip on Hannah’s ankles slackening. “Don’t you dare drop her, Liam,” Gareth snarled, not out of anger but sheer terror. The command seemed to find a spark in Liam, who tightened his hold, his knuckles white. Gareth moved backwards down the stairs, one cautious step at a time, bearing the brunt of the weight, the muscles in his thighs burning, his own lungs feeling as if they were full of hot sand.

They burst out of the communal door into the hazy, yellow light of the street. The air outside was no elixir, but it was thinner, less concentrated than the toxic soup in the hallway. Gareth sucked in a breath that was still painful, but felt like oxygen after the suffocation inside. He didn't pause. He half-dragged, half-carried his part of their burden across the pavement to the Land Rover. “Open the back,” he grunted at Liam. Liam fumbled with the handle, his fingers seemingly refusing to obey him, but finally managed to pull the heavy door open. Together, they manoeuvred Hannah onto the back seat, an awkward, undignified process that left her lying in a heap on the worn upholstery.

Liam collapsed against the side of the truck, his body wracked with another fit of coughing, his forehead pressed against the cold metal. He looked utterly broken. There was no time for comfort, no time for ‘I told you so’. Gareth grabbed him by the collar of his ridiculously bright jumper, now stained with grime, and bundled him into the front passenger seat as if he were a sack of feed. He slammed the door shut, ran around to the driver's side, and threw himself behind the wheel. He slammed his own door, sealing the three of them inside the cab. For a moment, there was only the sound of Liam's agonised breathing and the quiet ticking of the cooling engine. Gareth looked at his partner, slumped and gasping, and at the reflection of the still, silent woman in the rearview mirror. He had found them. Now he just had to get them out alive. He simply looked at her, his sharp eyes taking in the soot on her cheek, the dark smudges of exhaustion under her eyes, and the newfound steel in her posture. He’d left a sullen, angry girl in this chair and returned to find a woman in her place. “I hear you had a rough night with him,” he said, nodding towards Gareth.

“His fever was bad,” Hannah confirmed, her voice low. “He was thrashing. I used cold compresses.”

Arthur’s gaze sharpened, dropping to her shoulder where the dark fabric of her jumper was slightly askew. “He catch you with one of his flailing arms?” he asked, his tone matter-of-fact. Hannah instinctively touched her shoulder, surprised he had noticed. “It’s fine. A bruise.” Arthur gave a short, sharp nod. “Let me see your arm.” He took her pulse, checked her breathing with a cursory listen, his expression unreadable. “You’re the strongest of the lot of them,” he pronounced, a statement of fact, not praise. “Probably because you’ve spent the last twenty-four hours running on fear instead of adrenaline. More sustainable, in the short term.” He looked her directly in the eye. “You did well, lass. You kept them alive.”

The quiet, unadorned words landed with more force than any effusive praise could have. They were a validation, a recognition of her trial by fire. Hannah felt a hot flush of tears behind her eyes and blinked them back furiously. She simply nodded, unable to speak.

Arthur stood in the middle of the room, their doctor, their jailer, and their only link to the world they had fled. “Right,” he said, addressing them all. “The news from outside. The cordon around Hartlepool is still in place, but they’re starting to let essential services through. The official story is a chemical fire at the plant, contained now, but the leak was worse than they’re admitting publicly. They’re doing a house-to-house search of the exclusion zone. They’re finding people. The hospitals are full. As far as the world is concerned,” he paused, letting the weight of his next words sink in, “the three of you are currently unaccounted for. Liam’s car is on a list. His and Hannah’s names are on another. You, Gareth, for the moment, are simply a loose end they haven’t tied up yet.”

The implications were stark and terrifying. They were not just sick; they were fugitives from a disaster, ghosts in their own lives. “So what do we do?” Liam asked, his voice barely a whisper.

“You do nothing,” Arthur commanded. “You stay here. You rest. You drink water. You finish your course of antibiotics. You let your lungs heal. In a week, you’ll be weak, but you’ll be people again. Then, you can decide how you want to reappear in the world. But for the next seven days, this farm is your entire universe. No phones, no internet, no contact. Am I clear?”

They all murmured their assent, a chorus of chastened patients. Arthur seemed satisfied. He placed fresh vials and another box of pills on the mantelpiece. “Same again. I’ll be back in two days unless you call me. And I expect to see all three of you sitting up and complaining about the quality of the soup by then.” He turned to leave, but paused in the doorway and looked back at Hannah. “You’ll need to get some more logs from the shed out back,” he said. “This one,” he nodded at Gareth, “is to do nothing more strenuous than breathe. You’re in charge of the fire now.” It wasn’t a suggestion. It was a transfer of command. Then, with a final, curt nod, he was gone, leaving them alone in the new world he had just defined for them: a world of quiet convalescence, of shared history and uncertain futures, a world with a new, unlikely guardian at its heart.The heavy thud of the back door closing behind Arthur Webb echoed in the room, sealing them into their new reality. The world had been officially shrunk to the four walls of the farmhouse. For a long moment, nobody spoke. The silence was different now; it was no longer the tense, watchful quiet of a hospital bedside, but the deep, strange stillness of a ship becalmed after a storm, its crew weary and its destination unknown. The fire, which Hannah had diligently fed through the night, was beginning to burn low again, a visual reminder of the constant, necessary work of survival.

“He’s right,” Hannah said, her voice quiet but firm, breaking the spell. “The fire.” She looked at the depleted log basket, then at Gareth, slumped in the armchair. This was his domain, his task. But Arthur’s final words had been a clear directive, a formal handing over of a key. She pulled the horse blanket, which she had come to think of as her uniform, more tightly around her shoulders and walked towards the back door. “I’ll get them.” Gareth’s mouth opened as if to protest, to offer instructions, but he closed it again, a flicker of frustration crossing his face before it was replaced by a profound, weary acceptance. He simply nodded, a tiny inclination of his head, and watched her go.

The air outside was cold and clean, a shock to her system after the close, human-scented warmth of the house. It smelled of damp earth and the distant, clean scent of the sea, a world away from the chemical tang of Hartlepool that still seemed to cling to the inside of her nostrils. She followed a worn path across the yard to a large, open-fronted shed. The moment she stepped under its roof, she stepped into Gareth’s world. It was a cathedral of quiet competence. Tools hung in neat, orderly rows on the walls, each hook and nail perfectly placed. Sacks of feed were stacked with geometric precision. The air smelled of sawdust, old iron, and a faint, not unpleasant scent of engine oil. It was a space that spoke of a man who found solace in order, who built his life with his own two hands. She felt like an intruder, but also like a student in a silent classroom.

In the far corner was a huge, neatly stacked wall of logs, sorted by size. It was an intimidating sight, a testament to seasons of labour she couldn't begin to imagine. She started with the smaller pieces, gathering them into her arms. They were heavier than they looked, their rough bark digging into the soft skin of her inner arms. She was weak, her body still fighting the dregs of the sickness, and the small pile she managed to gather felt pathetic. Gritting her teeth, she went back for more, this time grabbing a couple of the larger, denser logs. She staggered back towards the house, her arms aching, her breath misting in the cold air, a small, determined figure carrying a burden that was both a chore and a responsibility.

She stumbled back into the living room, dropping the logs with a clatter into the basket by the hearth. The noise made both men jump. She ignored them, her focus entirely on the task. Kneeling down, she began to rebuild the fire with the careful, deliberate movements she had perfected during her long night watch. A piece of kindling first, then the smaller logs, leaving gaps for the air to circulate. Gareth watched from his chair, his hands clenched on the armrests, the instinct to take over, to correct, to do it *right*, warring with the leaden weakness in his limbs. "The damper," he croaked, his voice rough with disuse. "On the left. Open it a crack more." Hannah paused, then reached up and adjusted the small lever on the flue, her movements precise. She didn't question him. It was not a battle of wills anymore; it was a collaboration. The flames caught, licking hungrily at the fresh wood, and the room was once again filled with a steady, life-giving warmth. She had done it. She was in charge of the fire.

The day fell into a new, quiet rhythm. A routine of forced rest and shared, simple tasks. While Gareth and Liam slept, drifting in and out of a healing, medicated haze, Hannah became the house’s custodian. She warmed the rest of the soup for lunch, the three of them eating in a near-total silence that was no longer awkward, but companionable. She washed the few dishes in the sink, the warm, soapy water on her hands a small, grounding pleasure. She found a book on a shelf—a collection of poetry by a writer she’d never heard of—and sat in her chair, not reading, but just holding it, the quiet presence of the words a comfort. She was the sentinel, the keeper of the flame, and the role settled on her not as a burden, but as a purpose.

Later that afternoon, as the light outside began to fade to a soft, bruised purple, Liam woke properly. He watched her for a while as she sat staring into the fire, lost in thought. "You're good at that," he said softly. Hannah started, pulled from her reverie. "What?" "The fire," he clarified, gesturing with his head. "You look like you've been doing it your whole life." She snorted, a small, wry sound. "Hardly. I think the last thing I built was a tower of empty beer cans in my first year of uni." The casual, self-deprecating comment about her old life hung in the air, a ghost at their quiet convalescence.

Liam’s expression grew serious. He looked at his sister, truly looked at her, and saw not the angry, defensive girl who had slammed a door in his face, but a tired, brave woman who had faced down a night of terror for him. "Hannah," he began, his voice low and hesitant. "Last night... I don't really remember much. Was it... was it bad?"

Hannah considered her answer. She could spare him the details, protect him as he had always tried to protect her. But the time for that was over. The truth, stripped of drama, was what they needed now. "It was bad," she said, her gaze steady. "Gareth's fever was... high. He was delirious for a while." She paused, then decided to offer him a small, strange piece of the truth she had witnessed. "He talked. In his sleep." A flicker of alarm crossed Liam’s face. "What did he say?"

"He talked about the farm. About fixing a fence. And he talked about a cake," she said, watching his face. "Something about bilberries, and a woman named Prudence, and not wanting her to pull a face like she was sucking a wasp." A ghost of a smile touched Liam's lips, a sad, fond expression. "The Bake Off," he murmured, more to himself than to her. "The bloody final." He looked from Hannah to the sleeping form of his partner, and the full, crushing weight of the situation seemed to land on him. "It was on Tuesday, Hannah. The grand final of The Great British Bake Off. He was in it. He was going to win it. I was so sure. I filled in the application, I filmed his video, I… I built this whole narrative for him." He shook his head, his voice thick with a fresh wave of guilt. "And he threw it all away. To come and get me. Because I had to come and get you." He finally looked at her, his eyes shining with unshed tears. "That's what he gave up." And in that moment, Hannah finally understood the true cost of their fractured past, the scale of the sacrifice that had been laid, unasked, at the foot of their broken sibling bond. It was a debt so immense she knew she could never repay it, but could only hope to honour it, starting now, in the quiet, fire-lit room of their shared sanctuary.### Chapter 10

The words settled in the quiet room, as heavy and indelible as stone. *The Grand Final.* Hannah stared at Gareth, a still, sleeping giant in the armchair, and the image she had of him fractured and re-formed into something new, something breathtaking. This wasn't just a man who had missed a day of work. This was a man who had walked away from the crowning moment of a secret, second life. A life of passion and precision that existed in parallel to the mud and muck she had so dismissively defined him by. The flour still caught in his eyebrows was not just the dust of the farm; it was the mark of his art. She thought of his delirious ramblings about bilberries and the wasp-sucking face of a judge named Prudence. It hadn't been madness; it had been the ghost of a dream he was losing, even in his sleep.

Liam’s face was a mask of wretched misery. He scrubbed at his eyes with the back of his hand, a gesture of futility against the tide of his guilt. “I pushed him into it,” he whispered, his voice cracking. “I made him believe he could be this… this folk hero. I built the story. And then I made him choose between his own story and mine.” He looked at his sister, his expression one of complete devastation. “I ruin things, Hannah. That’s what I do. I ruined us, and now I’ve ruined this for him.”

“No,” Hannah said, the word sharp and immediate. She crossed the room and sat on the floor by the sofa, forcing him to look at her. “He chose. He’s a grown man, Liam. He heard about a chemical leak and he knew you were a stupid, loyal idiot who would run straight into it. So he made a choice. He chose you.” Her own words surprised her, the clarity of them. This wasn't about blame. It was simpler, and far more profound, than that. “He chose you over a cake competition. I’d say that makes him a hero, just not the kind you can put on television.”

She left him with that thought, a small offering of absolution, and retreated to the kitchen. She needed to do something, anything, to quiet the roaring in her own head. The kitchen, Gareth’s domain, felt different now. It wasn’t just a place for making soup; it was a studio, a laboratory. Her eyes scanned the shelves, the countertops, searching for a clue to this other man. And then she saw it, tucked away on a cool slate shelf in the pantry, just as he’d described in his fever-dream. A large glass jar, covered with a muslin cloth. Inside was a bubbling, beige-coloured substance that smelled faintly of sour apples and yeast. His sourdough starter. The thing he had conducted whispered, one-sided conversations with. The thing he had apologized to when he’d neglected it. It looked sluggish, a few sad bubbles rising to the surface. It was another casualty of the last two days, another living thing he cared for that had been left to fend for itself.

On an impulse she didn't fully understand, she lifted the jar and placed it on the large wooden worktop. She found a bag of stone-ground wholemeal flour in a ceramic crock and a canister of water. She had no idea what she was doing. She was a woman who lived on takeaways and toast, a stranger to the patient alchemy of baking. But she measured a scoop of flour and a splash of water into the jar, her movements hesitant and clumsy. She stirred it with a wooden spoon, trying to infuse the act with the same intention she had seen in Gareth’s hands. It was a pathetic, fumbling attempt to honour him, to care for a small piece of his abandoned dream.

“What are you doing?” The voice, low and gravelly, made her jump so violently that she nearly dropped the jar. Gareth was standing in the doorway, leaning heavily against the frame, his face pale and drawn but his eyes clear and sharp. He was watching her, his expression a mixture of profound confusion and something else, something she couldn't read.

“I… I heard you talking,” she stammered, feeling like a child caught doing something forbidden. “In your sleep. You were worried about it. Your starter. It looked… sad. I was just giving it some flour.” She gestured uselessly at the jar, her face burning with embarrassment.

Gareth looked from her face to the jar on his worktop, then back again. He was silent for a long moment, processing the impossible sight of his partner’s estranged, angry sister standing in his kitchen, ineptly tending to his sourdough. A slow, weary smile touched the corners of his mouth. It was the first time she had seen him smile. It transformed his tired, rugged face into something gentle and impossibly kind. “A bit more water,” he said, his voice a quiet rasp. “It likes to be the consistency of thick paint.” He pushed himself off the doorframe and shuffled slowly to the table, sinking into a chair with a low groan, his brief burst of energy spent. He didn't take over. He didn't criticize. He just sat at his own table and gave her instructions, a quiet teacher guiding his most unlikely student. “And stir it from the bottom. That’s where the good stuff is.”

Liam appeared in the doorway then, drawn by the sound of their voices. He stood, leaning against the frame just as Gareth had, and watched the scene: his sister, her face smudged with flour, carefully stirring a jar of bubbling yeast, while his partner, looking frail but present, gave quiet instructions from the kitchen table. The frantic, storyboarded narrative was gone, replaced by this quiet, strange, and deeply authentic moment. The kitchen was filled with a peace that felt more real than any hashtag.

It was in that moment of profound, healing quiet that the telephone on the wall let out a sudden, shrill, piercing ring. The sound was an assault, a violent intrusion from a world they had forgotten. All three of them froze, their heads snapping towards the sound as if a gunshot had been fired. It rang again, a harsh, demanding summons. No one moved. They were united in their stillness, a trinity of fugitives. The ringing stopped, and was followed by the loud, mechanical clunk of the ancient answering machine kicking in. A moment of static, and then a woman’s voice, bright, professional, and terrifyingly normal, filled the kitchen.

“Hi Gareth, it’s Sarah from Love Productions. We’re just calling… again. Everyone was so worried when you didn’t arrive for the final. We’ve tried your mobile, but it’s going straight to voicemail. We just want to know you’re okay. It’s not like you to just disappear. Please, give us a call as soon as you get this.” There was a pause, a faint sigh on the line. “We hope you’re alright, Gaz. The tent wasn’t the same without you.” Another clunk, and then silence. A silence more profound and absolute than any that had come before. The secret was no longer a secret. It was out, a disembodied voice hanging in the air between them, a testament to the life Gareth had left behind on a roadside in Hartlepool. He didn’t look at Liam or Hannah. He just stared at his own large, capable hands resting on the oak of the kitchen table, as if seeing them for the first time.The silence that descended was a new element in the room, different from the tense quiet of sickness or the companionable quiet of shared soup. This silence was a vacuum, created by the sudden intrusion of a world that was supposed to be sealed off. It was thick with the ghost of the producer's cheerful, concerned voice, with the weight of hashtags and showstoppers and a life of bright lights and buttercream that had been happening, concurrently, just beyond the horizon of the Eston Hills. Gareth continued to stare at his hands on the table. They looked like foreign objects to him. These were the hands that could coax a perfect crumb from a difficult dough, that understood the precise temperature for proofing, that could craft a delicate lattice of spun sugar. They were also the hands that had hauled his partner from a toxic flat, scrubbed poison from his sister-in-law's skin, and built a fire in the dead of night to ward off a fever. The two identities felt irreconcilable, and the man who owned these hands felt like a fraud in both worlds.

Liam, leaning in the doorway, physically seemed to shrink. The cheerful voice from London, the casual affection in the phrase ‘Gaz’, the simple, devastating fact that they were worried, that he was missed, was a hundred times more damning than his own internal monologue of guilt. He had known, abstractly, what he was asking Gareth to leave behind. But hearing it, spoken in the language of that other life, made it a concrete, monstrous crime. He had not just pulled his partner away from an opportunity; he had torn him from a community, a place where he was valued and happy. A place where Liam himself had pushed him to go. He couldn't look at Gareth. He squeezed his eyes shut, as if he could block out the sound of his own colossal failure.

It was Hannah who moved first. Her gaze flickered from Liam's crumpled form to Gareth’s rigid, silent back. She saw the full, devastating circuit of love and sacrifice and guilt laid bare between them. The old Hannah, the one from three days ago, would have seen this as a victory, a crack in their perfect life she could exploit. But the woman standing in the kitchen, her hands still faintly sticky from feeding a sourdough starter, felt only a profound, aching sorrow. With a quiet deliberation that felt monumental, she picked up the wooden spoon and gave the starter one last, gentle stir. It was a small, seemingly insane gesture in the face of the emotional cataclysm, but it was an act of continuation. It was a choice. This is what is real now. This bubbling pot of yeast, this kitchen, this man.

She placed the spoon down softly on the counter. "So," she said, her voice small but clear in the heavy silence. "Prudence. Does she really suck wasps for a living, or is that just a hobby?"

The absurdity of the question, the sheer, gentle ridiculousness of it, was a pinprick in a giant, over-inflated balloon. Liam opened his eyes, a choked, half-strangled sound that might have been a sob or a laugh escaping his throat. Gareth didn't turn around, but the rigid line of his shoulders softened almost imperceptibly. The question acknowledged everything without demanding anything. It was a gift of deflection, a ladder out of the pit of suffocating silence.

Gareth finally pushed his chair back, the legs scraping loudly against the stone floor. He stood up, but he didn't turn to face them. He walked slowly to the kitchen window, the one that looked out past the yard, over the winter-bare fields towards the hulking, familiar shape of Roseberry Topping in the distance. He braced his hands on the windowsill, his head bowed. He was a farmer looking at his land. It was his anchor, his truth, the one thing that had been real before baking and before Liam and would be real long after. This view had seen him through the death of his parents, through bitter winters and failed crops and the solitary ache of a lonely life. It was seeing him through this, too.

"No," he said at last, his voice a low rumble directed at the glass. "It's just her face when she tries something she thinks is 'overly rustic'." He took a deep, shuddering breath of the air in his own kitchen, which still smelled faintly of soup and woodsmoke. "Liam." He said the name without turning, a simple, quiet command. "Go and sit down on the sofa before you fall over. You look like a ghost." The words were blunt, practical, devoid of anger or accusation. It was the most profound act of forgiveness he could offer: the simple, mundane continuation of care. He had made his choice two days ago, and he was making it again, now, by turning his back on the ghost in the answering machine and focusing on the living, breathing man in his house.
